questions.question: What access control enforces system-wide mandatory policies?
questions.explanation: MAC enforces centralized security policies users can't override. It's used in high-security environments.

questions.question: What access control lets owners set permissions?
questions.explanation: DAC allows resource owners to control access. It's flexible but can be insecure.

questions.question: What access control uses roles to assign permissions?
questions.explanation: RBAC assigns permissions through roles. It simplifies administration in large systems.

questions.question: What attack manipulates return addresses?
questions.explanation: ROP chains existing code gadgets to bypass DEP. It reuses legitimate instructions maliciously.

questions.question: What technique detects stack corruption?
questions.explanation: Stack canaries place values before return addresses. Corruption is detected when values change.

questions.question: What sandbox isolates untrusted code?
questions.explanation: Sandboxing restricts program capabilities to contain damage. It limits system access.

questions.question: What technique verifies software integrity?
questions.explanation: Code signing uses digital signatures to verify authenticity. It ensures code hasn't been tampered with.

questions.question: What SELinux mechanism defines fine-grained policies?
questions.explanation: Type enforcement assigns types to subjects and objects. It enforces access rules between types.

questions.question: What Chinese Wall model prevents conflicts of interest?
questions.explanation: Brewer-Nash prevents accessing competing organizations' data. It enforces dynamic separation.

questions.question: What formal method proves security properties?
questions.explanation: Formal verification mathematically proves correctness. It provides strong security guarantees.
